title: The KGB had equally misplaced fears about British penetration. In 1942-1943 the KGB suspected that three of its most valuable spies inside the British government, Kim Philby, Anthony Blunt, and Guy Burgess, were double agents because it had difficulty believing their reports that after the development of the British-Soviet alliance the British had drastically reduced their intelligence actions directed at the USSR. The KGB's response to the same events had been the opposite: to see the British-Soviet alliance as an opportunity to increase its espionage assault on Great Britain
